Has anyone seen the HBO movie, "Temple Grandin"? It's amazing.
One key phrase in the movie was that Temple was "different, but not less." And she lucked into a science teacher who recognized Temple had a very special mind that could see things that "normal" people could not. She's written books. Check her out.

There is a winery north of Tokyo that has autistic adults working on the bottling line and doing other tasks around the winery. I have worked side by side with these amazing people and am inspired by them. CNN did a short video that shows why this is a win-win for both the winery and the students. I have been to wineries all over the world but this one is by far the most special.

http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/04/01/japan.autism/index.html

I'm autistic, and I have a successful career by any standard. My fields (quantitative finance, information technology) are chock full of people on the spectrum. Even some of the bosses. One company I worked for, probably at least half the people there were --- the human interaction wasn't always what one would want. These are all very capable, highly skilled, highly paid people. Detail-oriented? Intense interests? Narrow focus? These are the elements that lead to success in my field.

Many of us managed to find our way where we are by figuring things out over time. Some specialized career-skills vocational training like this could certainly have helped in making career entry.

My 16 year old daughter has Asperger's. She generally comes up around 98th percentile in the various testing at school, but people don't understand why she's "weird," and they are mean to her or treat her as if she's retarded (talking to her like she's three - I know this happens to people in wheelchairs too). I have worried and wondered what kind of work she will be able to do when she's out of school, and it's interesting that after years of pondering, the one thing my husband and I agreed she would be ideally suited for is software testing. But while the work would be perfect for her, and she would do an exceptional job, most workplaces would be terrifying. There are so many unspoken, unclear expectations, and she would never know what they were. The only place where she is really comfortable and happy in online, where all communication is done with words, with no facial expressions to read, no eye contact expected, no judgment of her unstylish appearance.

Someone else mentioned a brother with Asperger's who tunes pianos. The man who came and tuned our piano last year also had Asperger's. It took me about five minutes to recognize it. He didn't make any of the normal small talk, or eye contact, but when he noticed some interesting decorative work in the inside of the circa 1895 piano, he gave my husband an exhaustive history lesson on it, which was much appreciated. And he tuned the piano perfectly. Piano tuning and software testing are very similar jobs, just in different fields.

People like Mr. Sonne enhance my belief that people are inherently good. Just given a chance everybody can make a contribution to make this a better world and to live a happier life. I just wish that Mr. Sonne initiative can be replicated in many more places around the world, so that many more people with Asperger's Syndrome can find their deserved happiness.

I  watched my young nephew grow up with autism.  He was fortunate to have wonderfully caring parents and a school system that mainstreamed him as much as possible.  He is now 21 and, though far from being "ordinary", can - given the right support and surroundings - lead a good life.  It is opportunities like the one provided by Thorkil Sonne that will come as a godsend for people like him.

Up-lifting article.  It would appear that if we looked we would find that all of us are somewhere along that spectrum but most of us are within the 2 standard deviations.  Regimentation is the bane of some and the savior of others.

I am a mother of a son currently in training at Aspiritech, a non-for-profit who employs individuals with autism. I can relate to how my son is understood and is seen as an herb, not a weed, as stated it this great article.  What a great first job experience where as a mother I do not have to worry, because I know he is being coached and praised for his unique talent and abilities.  Thank you.

As the mother of a 43-year-old who committed suicide a few years ago,because he could not cope with his life, which was diagnosed as serious depression recurrent, the late writing about the new and broader autism spectrum has convinced me that my son from early childhood displayed some symptoms of this illlness. I'm not suggesting that having realized that would have prevented his suicide, as at the time he died, he was in two excellent programs that seemed to be helping him. It was knowing that his life would probably never improve to "normalcy" that led to his suicide.

I was first alerted to the possibility of autism as a possible contributor to my son's condition by reading the books of Temple Grandin, a high-functioning autistic individual with a Ph.D. She described symptoms that such children may exhibit from early childhood, which my son did, and which my husband and I then thought was "cute." In fact, he was extremely anxious from a very young age, worrying about how he would know how to pay taxes when he was older, how he would know who to marry, what if he had to be a soldier, and more terrible and terribly deep questions that kept him from sleeping a full night for three years, while he was a patient of a psychologist who termed his anxieties "minimal brain dysfunction," a popular term of the 60s, and treated with Ritalin, which only increased his symptoms.

He was also a brilliant student. He graduated at the top of his high school class, went on to Harvard, wrote a summa grade thesis, and was still hoping to become a psychologist, as his disabilities became more obvious. That wish did not come to pass, but he did became a part--time writer, which was his newest dream, and one that I believe could have been realized had he the strength of mind he needed. But instead, he gave up.

Articles like this one are a joy to me. To see the positive potentials that are possible for people suffering as my son did gives me a lift, even though he is gone
In addition to Aspiritech & Specialisterne there is also Uzmanlar Danismanlik in Turkey, Autism Works in the UK and Kaien in Japan for those of you looking in other parts of the world.
Looks like a real prima donna.  Good luck trying that in MLB

It was really wonderful to read this article. Gave me a warm feeling inside. I have a grandkid, a 4-year-old boy who has been dignosed for Autism, after having developped neurologically the normal way until he was around one and half years old. Then my daughter-in-law started to observe some changes in his behavior. He had to undergo so many exams! It was always an emotional pain to go get the results. I guess that when he had to go test for hearing, we, inside our most hidden selves, we wish he had a hearing problem. That would be  much less painful news than knowing he didn´t respond to any stimuli because he had autism. He has been developping quite well and is overcoming, little by little, his difficulties. But there´s still a long road to go. He´s having different types of therapies and is going to a normal school, but one that makes the inclusion of kids like him possible.  He doesn´t speak yet. But he is already uttering some syllables. We keep our hopes high. I also want to thank all the readers that contributed with their own experiences. That´s great to feel we´re not alone in our worries and anxieties.

This was an excellent article. Thank you so much for sharing. I am a special education teacher for a high school program that supports Asperger's and ASD students. Transition out of high school and into the real world is by far the most troubling and challenging issue we face.

This illustrates a powerful message and practice for enabling the challenged within industries and our societies at large. I marvel at my local supermarket's hiring practice and the successes so obvious within this venue.

In response to #30-KM FROM NJ's post:

You could not be more incorrect. You start by saying one thing, give some statistics which, depending on when they were done, could be accurate, to saying in a new paragraph that the dominant cause of ASD is apparent - and giving the link to a non-proven site. As the parent of a 20 year old autistic son, as well as a Researcher, a Parent Advocate, a blogger and member of autism speaks, and an associate of the top neurologists in the country NO ONE knows the dominant cause of ASD. What seems to be for some, has absolutely no relevance to others. To make a statement like that is irresponsible and dangerous. It gives false hope to those looking for an answer. There is no answer. Yet. I believe there will be, but right now try things that work for some - they may work - they may not. If they don't, to all you parents out there, trust your gut . . . If after a fair amount of time, whatever you are trying doesn't seem to be working - move on! We did the whole dairy gluten elimination for almost a year and the only thing that happened was that it made us all crazy. My son has many things, including diabetes, which is very well controlled by diet, but he NEVER suffered from diarrhea or constipation. When a "REAL" reason, solution or cure comes along, we will all know and it won't be from reading it on a blog!

At Aspiritech, we see each and every day how, given the right structure, training and support, but most importantly, the right type of work, we can transform the vocational experience for high functioning adults with autism.

Our testers excel at software testing and we have client company testimonials to prove it!

Aspiritech, founded in 2008, has created a US-based model that makes sound business sense and creates a solution for a growing social problem-the 85-90% unemployment/underemployment rate for people with ASD.

Aspiritech has 11 testers with autism on our payroll, a full-time autism specialist (thank you Autism Speaks and Healthcare Foundation of HP) and literally hundreds more eager to get trained and start working! We have a model that could be replicated elsewhere in the US and we did all this without any seed funding.

We could be doing much more if we had the support. How? Companies-contact us for your QA needs-we have a highly capable domestic workforce ready to jump in! Contact Moshe Weitzberg, PhD, at 312-945-TEST (8378).

Funders, donors-We are a non profit business. Please check out how you can help on our website www.aspiritech.org.

Thanks for a great and important article about our inspiration-Specialisterne!

To Betty Sher....you can have back problems at any weight.  I was 29 and 120 lbs 5ft 5 Inches the first time I threw my back out- bad enough to make me see stars and go to the doctor.  A desk job combined with running as my only exercise was the problem...12 hour workdays sitting at a computer wreaks havoc on your core.

The book recommended by on-the-road (http://www.amazon.com/Trigger-Point-Therapy-Workbook-Self-Treatment/dp/1... is an invaluable resource which helped me to understand the source of my pains and the simple methods to relieve it - I would highly recommend it.

In addition, regular yoga practice (both restorative and hatha), self massage using Yamuna body rolling balls and techniques (yamunabodyrolling.com), the use of the lacrosse ball and a theracane (with the guidance of the Trigger Point Therapy Workbook) and monthly myofascial release massages are my methods of keeping my whole body relatively pain free.

While I agree that the literature is inconclusive on a "July effect," there is some pretty convincing data that a "weekend effect" exists; that is, when hospitals are short staffed morbidity and mortality are higher. Here's a link to one of the best studies:

http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa063355

I lament about why hospitals run this way here:

http://glasshospital.com/2011/05/11/1st-gear-weekends/

For more debate about short staffing at hospitals (every weekend! even the best!): read this web debate here:

http://healthaffairs.org/blog/2011/05/23/just-another-hospital-weekend-o...

-Dr. John

A few years ago I moved to a large southern city and had to look for a new primary care physician.  When I reached a certain medical office, by telephone, I heard laughing/giggling at the other end of the line and finally a "hello."  That person unexpectedly offered me an appointment on a Saturday, which I gladly accepted, so that I would not have to miss work at my new job.  However, a few days later, the office called me back and said that Saturday appointments were only for patients already seen in that practice.  I declined their offer of another appointment, because after these two incidents, I decided, without ever having met the physician, that the office was not professional.  First impressions do mean a lot.
